Description: On October 13, 2011, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement issued a Consent Order to URS Energy & Construction, Inc. associated with nuclear safety-related deficiencies in the contractor's corrective action management, quality improvement, and work control programs associated with the Sodium Bearing Waste Treatment Project at DOE's Idaho National Laboratory. The contractor agreed to the Consent Order.
Info Source: http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/hss/Enforcement%20and%20Oversight/Enforcement/docs/consentorders/URS_Signed_Consent_Order_%28NCO-2011-02%29%282%29.pdf

Description: On September 1, 2011, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement and Oversight issued a Preliminary Notice of Violation (NEA-2011-04) for violations of 10 C.F.R. Parts 830 and 835 associated with a radiological contamination event that occurred on September 29, 2010, during building demolition at DOE's Separations Process Research Unit.
Info Source: http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/hss/Enforcement%20and%20Oversight/Enforcement/docs/eas/NEA-2011-04.pdf

Description: On October 3, 2011, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Health, Safety and Security's Office of Enforcement and Oversight issued a Preliminary Notice of Violation (WEA-2011-01) to URS-Washington Division for violations of 10 C.F.R. 851 associated with an October 4, 2010, hoisting incident that occurred when a telescopic gantry system tipped while lifting a shield plug at the Sodium Waste Bearing Treatment Project at DOE's Idaho National Laboratory.
Info Source: http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/hss/Enforcement%20and%20Oversight/Enforcement/docs/eas/WEA-2011-01.pdf

Description: Bechtel and URS agreed to pay a total of $125 million to resolve allegations that in the design and on-going construction of the U.S. Department of Energy's Waste Treatment & Immobilization Plant project in Hanford, Washington they falsely represented and charged DOE for deficient goods and services, which failed to be of the highest quality for nuclear facilities.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-edwa/pr/bni-and-urs-pay-125-million-resolving-alleged-false-claims-regarding-deficient-nuclear

Description: URS CORPORATION AES entered into a civil settlement agreement with the federal government in which URS agreed to pay $580,000 to resolve allegations that it violated the federal False Claims Act and the common law in overbilling the federal government on a bridge reconstruction project in Niantic that was funded by Amtrak.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-ct/pr/urs-corporation-aes-pay-580k-resolve-allegations-it-overcharged-niantic-river-bridge

Description: Tishman Construction entered into a deferred prosecution agreement in which it admitted to fraudulently overbilling clients and agreed to pay more than $20 million in restitution to victims and penalties to the federal government. The company also agreed to instituted far-reaching corporate reforms.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of New York
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-edny/pr/tishman-construction-charged-fraud-pay-more-20-million-restitution-and-penalties

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: February 7, 2020 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/sites/dolgov/files/ofccp/foia/files/2020-08-10AECOM_CA_SW_Redacted.pdf

Description: Bechtel National Inc., Bechtel Corporation, AECOM Energy & Construction, Inc., and their subsidiary Waste Treatment Completion Company LLC, agreed to pay $57,750,000 to the U.S. Department of Justice to resolve claims that Bechtel and AECOM fraudulently overcharged the U.S. Department of Energy in connection with its operation of the Hanford Waste Treatment Plant project. The False Claims Act claims arose from allegations that Bechtel and AECOM management were aware of and failed to prevent inflated labor hours being charged to DOE, and for falsely billing DOE for work not actually performed. The settlement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here half of the total is attributed to each firm.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-edwa/pr/bechtel-aecom-us-department-energy-doe-contractors-agree-pay-5775-million-resolve-0

Description: Bard Manufacturing Company, Inc.; Burnham Holdings, Inc.; Carrier Corporation; Chromalox; Crane; Climate Master, Inc.; Empire Comfort Systems; General Electric Company; Honeywell International Inc.; Hunter Fan Company; Invensys, Inc.; ITT Corporation; Johnson Controls; Lear Siegler; Lennox International Inc.; Lux Products; The Marley-Wylain Company; Nortek Global HVAC, LLC; Sears Holdings; Thomas & Betts Corporation; Trane Residential Systems; Uponor, Inc.; Vaillant Corporation; W. W. Grainger; and  White-Rodgers agreed to jointly pay a total of $625,000 in settlement of allegations the companies failed to meet requirements to collect out of service mercury-added thermostats required by the state Health and Safety Code.
